Sales is sales so you better perform, or you will be replaced. Performance also includes being a team player and collaborator. Those who are not are rooted out very early. cons: The three top areas of Microsoft are Software Engineering, Sales, and Security. If you are in those areas your stress level will be significantly higher than any other position, but your value is also substantially higher than any other position in the company. So be prepared to work and work hard. The third-party contract recruiters are the worst. For a company that invests in so much into it's employees it has the most unprofessional and blatantly callas employment recruiters I am a majority of other new hires have ever experienced. My experience at Google was equally as horrible. The internal systems for sales and all other departments are disparate to say the least. Our customers have tools well beyond more functional that what is utilized at Microsoft. The amount of time wasted navigating to different tools to find accurate information is embarrassing. Most recruiters could care less about your value to Microsoft as a whole and will only care about their requirements for their bonuses. Be aware.

It's a good logo for the CV but don't get too comfy.
cons:
Avoid the Industry Solutions area of Microsoft like the plague. It was previously known as Microsoft Consulting Services (MCS). It is surplus to requirements, rudderless and pretty pointless as a business unit. 

Some managers are just pyramid builders who have no clue about tech or the industry in general. Some of them gauge their own success on team head count and nothing else.

Constant big company politics, with the need to justify your existence on a regular basis. 

The UK sub of Microsoft is virtually one big sales org. Don't expect to be doing anything deeply technical, unless you land in an Engineering role, which are thin on the ground. Loads of presales, loads of shoulder surfing.

Lower pay than FAANG/MANGA.

Slow career progression. It's more about years of experience than actual contributions. It's much easier to get a promotion by switching companies, and I imagine the pay increase at that new company would be much better than what MSFT gives you.

High-stress. I quit halfway through 2021 and I am still recovering from burnout from a gaslighting, rude manager.

Most of the people I worked with were disrespectful, petty, and standoffish. This is common across MSFT, even though I have seen a lot of feedback here saying MSFT is a wonderful place to work. The meme picture of Microsoft's org chart, where different teams are aiming pistols at each other, is painfully accurate. It is true that change has happened under Satya Nadella's leadership, but MSFT still lives under a rock compared to other companies today. I don't ever see this changing.
